questions.text: A research team studying metabolic responses to nutrient deprivation measures enzymatic activities in subjects after a 24-hour fast. They aim to determine which enzyme associated with lipid metabolism shows decreased activity in this energy-conserving state. Which enzyme is the research team least likely to find elevated in the fasting state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetyl CoA carboxylase

 

Option D:

 

  • Phosphorylation inactivates acetyl CoA carboxylase. Thus, AMP activated kinase (AMPK) phosphorylates acetyl CoA carboxylase and inactivates it
  • ATP inhibits AMPK, hence fatty acid synthesis is increased in a well-fed state.
  • Fatty acid synthesis decreases in fasting state
  • This enzyme is inhibited by palmitoyl CoA, the end product of fatty acid synthesis
  • Dephosphorylation of Acetyl CoA carboxylase is effected by protein phosphatase 1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: CPS–I: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is an enzyme in the urea cycle, which may have increased activity during fasting due to the breakdown of amino acids for gluconeogenesis, resulting in excess nitrogen that needs to be excreted as urea.

 

Option B: Hormone-sensitive lipase: This enzyme is responsible for breaking down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol, which is upregulated during fasting to provide energy.

 

Option C: Glycogen Phosphorylase: This enzyme breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which is then converted to glucose-6-phosphate for gluconeogenesis or energy production, and is thus upregulated during fasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During fasting, the body downregulates enzymes involved in synthesizing storage compounds, such as acetyl CoA carboxylase, while upregulating enzymes that facilitate the mobilization of stored nutrients, like hormone-sensitive lipase and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 238

choices.text: It is synthesized from lysine and methionine in liver and kidney
It is chemically Beta-hydroxy Gamma-Trimethyl amino butyrate
It is a transporter for short chain fatty acids
Vitamin B12 is essential for its synthesis

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a teenage girl presents with complaints of fatigue and muscle weakness. After conducting lab tests, the diagnosis points towards a carnitine deficiency. The attending physician explains to the girl and her parents about carnitine's role and its characteristics. Which of the following statements about carnitine is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is synthesized from lysine and methionine in the liver and kidney.

 

Options A:

 

  • Long-chain acyl-CoA (or FFA) cannot penetrate the inner membrane of mitochondria, So has to be carried by carnitine transporter (option C).
  • Carnitine is synthesized in the liver and kidneys from lysine and methionine.
  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is essential for the synthesis of carnitine (option D).
  • During growth or pregnancy, the requirement of carnitine might exceed its natural production

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It is chemically Beta-hydroxy Gamma-Trimethyl amino butyrate: This statement is a correct description of the chemical structure of carnitine, indicating that this option could also be considered correct.

 

Option C. It is a transporter for short chain fatty acids: Carnitine primarily facilitates the transport of long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for oxidation, not short-chain fatty acids.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 is essential for its synthesis: While vitamin B12 is essential for many metabolic processes, it is not directly involved in the synthesis of carnitine. The synthesis of carnitine requires lysine, methionine, and other cofactors like vitamin C, but not vitamin B12.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine, synthesized from lysine and methionine in the liver and kidneys, is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation

 

Ref: Harper30/e pg 224, Vasudevan 9/ed:p202

questions.text: Sources of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis include all the following reactions, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase

 

Option C:

 

  • This enzyme converts oxaloacetate to malate & utilizes one NADH
  • The co-enzyme utilized for de novo synthesis of fatty acid is NADPH.
  • The sources of  NADPH for fatty acid synthesis are:
    • Pentose Phosphate Pathway (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase).
    • Malic enzyme (Converts Malate to Pyruvate)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is the first in the pentose phosphate pathway and is a major source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis by oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone.

 

Option B: 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase: Also part of the pentose phosphate pathway, this enzyme further contributes to NADPH production by oxidizing 6-phosphogluconate to ribulose-5-phosphate.

 

Option D: Malic enzyme: This enzyme catalyzes the decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate, producing NADPH in the process, and serves as an additional source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase is not a source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis, unlike glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase, and the malic enzyme, which all contribute to NADPH production in the cytoplasm for biosynthetic processes such as fatty acid synthesis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 159.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In well-fed state, activity of acetyl CoA carboxylase activity is increased.


Reasoning (R): Citrate produced from acetyl CoA in well-fed state acts as an allosteric activator of acetyl CoA carboxylase:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A as well as R are right, and R is a Correct explanation of A

 

Option C:

 

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is an allosteric enzyme and is activated by citrate, which increases in concentration in a well-fed state and is also an indicator of a plentiful supply of acetyl-CoA.
  • Citrate favours conversion of the enzyme from an inactive dimer to an active polymeric form.

 

 

  • Inactivation is by phosphorylation of the enzyme and by long-chain acyl-CoA molecules such as palmitoyl CoA using feedback inhibition and inhibition of citrate transport from mitochondria to cytosol.                      

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl CoA carboxylase is an enzyme crucial in fatty acid synthesis. In a well-fed state, the abundance of acetyl CoA leads to the production of citrate, which can be transported out of the mitochondria into the cytosol.

 

Citrate serves as an allosteric activator of acetyl CoA carboxylase, increasing its activity. This upregulation is consistent with the body's shift toward anabolic processes, like fatty acid synthesis, when there is a surplus of energy.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 237-238

questions.text: Identify the metabolic pathway that specifically utilizes NADPH as a reducing agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fatty acid synthesis

 

Option A:

 

NADPH provides the reducing equivalents necessary for the biosynthesis of fatty acids. It is used in the reductive reactions of the fatty acid synthesis pathway, such as the conversion of acetoacetyl-ACP to malonyl-ACP, and is a critical factor in the synthesis of new fatty acid molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ketone synthesis: This process takes place predominantly in the mitochondria of liver cells during periods of carbohydrate scarcity and does not primarily use NADPH.

 

Option C: Gluconeogenesis: This is the pathway by which glucose is synthesized from non-carbohydrate precursors, and it does not typically involve NADPH.

 

Option D: Glycolysis: This is the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to pyruvate, generating ATP and NADH, not utilizing NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acid synthesis require Cofactors like: NADPH, ATP, Mn2+ , HCO3- , Biotin

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed ,p 232

questions.text: Identify which of the following is not utilized in the synthesis of fatty acids:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FADH2

 

Option C:

 

FADH2 is a reduced form of flavin adenine dinucleotide that is primarily involved as an electron carrier in the mitochondrial electron transport chain to produce ATP. It is not used as a direct substrate or cofactor in the biosynthetic pathway of fatty acids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: ATP: ATP provides the energy necessary for the activation of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA in the first step of fatty acid synthesis.

 

Option B: NADPH: NADPH is a reducing agent that donates electrons in the reductive biosynthetic steps of fatty acid synthesis.

 

Option D: HCO3- (bicarbonate): Bicarbonate serves as a source of the carboxyl group in the conversion of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA by acetyl-CoA carboxylase during fatty acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Two major enzyme complexes are involved in the synthesis of fatty acids.
  • The first is acetyl-CoA carboxylase, which synthesizes malonyl-CoA by  the  steps shown below for the synthesis of palmitate:
  • 7 acetyl-CoA + 7 HCO3- + 7 ATP → 7 malonyl-CoA + 7 ADP + 7 Pi
  • Using the malonyl-CoA, palmitate is then synthesized by seven cycles of the fatty acid synthetase complex, whose stoichiometry is summarized below:
  • acetyl-CoA + 7 malonyl-CoA + 14 NADPH → palmitate + 7 CO2 +14 NAD+ + 8 CoA + 6 H2O
  • As can be seen from the equations above, the necessary amount of malonyl-CoA is synthesized. Palmitate is subsequently synthesized from malonyl-CoA and one initial acetyl-CoA. Thus, acetyl-CoA, NADPH, ATP, and HCO3- are all necessary in this process.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 156-160

questions.text: In a laboratory studying cellular lipid metabolism, scientists are investigating the enzymatic pathways responsible for fatty acid modification. A particular focus is on understanding where in the cell long-chain fatty acids undergo elongation to produce extended lipid species. Which organelle is central to this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoplasmic reticulum

 

Option A:

 

The endoplasmic reticulum is the key organelle involved in the elongation of long-chain fatty acids. This process is crucial for the synthesis of various complex lipids that are integral to cellular membranes and signaling pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Golgi body: The Golgi apparatus is primarily involved in the modification, sorting, and packaging of proteins and lipids for secretion or use within the cell. It is not directly involved in the elongation of fatty acids.

 

Option C: Lysosomes: Lysosomes are organelles that contain digestive enzymes used for breaking down various biomolecules, cellular debris, and foreign pathogens. They are not involved in the synthesis or elongation of fatty acids.

 

Option D: Ribosomes: Ribosomes are the cellular structures responsible for protein synthesis, translating mRNA into polypeptide chains. They do not participate in fatty acid elongation or lipid metabolism directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Microsomal system (microsomal fatty acid elongase system) elongates saturated or unsaturated fatty acyl CoA by addition of two-carbon units successively.
  • Donor of 2 carbon acetyl groups: Malonyl CoA.
  • NADPH is needed for the reaction.
  • This system can elongate FA having 10C units onwards up to the length of 22 or 24C.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 186

questions.text: Fatty acid synthesis occurs outside the mitochondria. Is this statement true or false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TRUE

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

Fatty acid synthesis is indeed an extra-mitochondrial process, primarily occurring in the cytoplasm of cells. The cytoplasm houses the necessary enzymes for the de novo synthesis of fatty acids, distinguishing this pathway from mitochondrial processes like fatty acid oxidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acids are synthesized mainly by a de novo synthetic pathway operating in cytoplasm. So, it is referred to as an extramitochondrial or cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase system.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 156
